comment.author: 73509022@N00
comment._content: From Wikipedia: The second USS Astoria (CA-34) was a United States Navy New Orleans-class heavy cruiser that participated in both the Battle of the Coral Sea and the Battle of Midway, but was then sunk in August 1942 at the Battle of Savo Island. She visited Australia in the summer of 1934 (Northern hemisphere summer), but I have no idea if this is an image of that visit or a later one.

comment.author: 43355778@N03
comment._content: A careful look shows that this vessel doesn't match the hull design of any of the USS ASTORIA ships 1869-present

comment.author: 73509022@N00
comment._content: Hmm. I am no expert on between-war cruisers, but looking at the picture, she does seem to have ASTORIA written on her stern, and she is flying US colors. The cruiser Astoria did make a shakedown cruise to Australia in 1934, so that part lines up, as well. Images of CA-34 show her to mount one turret aft, with three guns, so that part matches. If one looks at this image of her, one sees the stern could possibly line up, too… Here is an image of CA-34 from her trials in 1934… And another from her cruise, this one in Peru. This one shows significant similarity, to my eye: Hard to say what else she could be if not CA-34.

comment.author: 51570155@N04
comment._content: After looking at the photograph i can confirm for me it is one of the 'New Orleans' class of heavy Cruiser, and the unmistakale old fashioned stern certianly gives it away.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: A very atttractive picture both of the ship and that BRIDGE.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/ranbarton] Hi ranbarton, you are correct. Upon closer examination of the photograph in our database, I can confirm that it does have ASTORIA on the stern. Thank you for the info. The Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background would also confirm its date as post 1932.
Regards, ANMM
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
